metadata.synopsis: Player speaks with Kagha, the secret Shadow druid. Various paths of conversation reflect whether Kagha's actions led to a child's death or not. She may be neutral/Machiavellian or pure evil, depending.
metadata.how_to_trigger: in reCon: teleport S_DEN_DruidLeaderplay through first dialogue (SnakesCourt). Your choices in that dialogue affect different paths in this oneclick on Kagha after to trigger this dialogue

12.speaker: Kagha
12.text: A deep elf - in our grove, on this day. A sign. Or rather, a gift.
12.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

35.speaker: Kagha
35.text: Who better to understand a watchful broodmother than a beloved child of Lolth?

7.speaker: Player
7.text: I'm nothing like you - I don't kill children.

141.speaker: Kagha
141.text: Bah. I'd thought one like you might understand. When a threat makes itself known, you remove it.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I don't make a habit of threatening children.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: You protected your own without hesitation - my compliments.

168.speaker: Kagha
168.text: And yet you petitioned on the thief's behalf. A curious display of mercy.

173.speaker: Kagha
173.text: Then we agree. Preservation is not luxury, it is not zealotry. It is necessity.

36.speaker: Player
36.text: I'd have killed the thief outright.

40.speaker: Kagha
40.text: And still you petitioned on her behalf. Your words are vicious, yet you showed mercy.

149.speaker: Kagha
149.text: A viper bares her fangs defending her brood. Is it not her nature to strike at invaders?

176.speaker: Kagha
176.text: Yes. Yes. This could be the true way of Silvanus.

192.speaker: Kagha
192.text: The viper bares her fangs defending her brood. It is only right that she strike the killing blow.

100.speaker: Kagha
100.text: The others might consider this sacrilege. But we know the truth: it is necessity.

118.speaker: Kagha
118.text: I took back the Idol of Silvanus and the rite has resumed. We will seal the grove. Free from harm. Free of intruders.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: Please - we have nothing in common.

1.speaker: Kagha
1.text: Don't we? I've studied duergar culture. You have an instinct for survival.

127.speaker: Kagha
127.text: A viper bares her fangs defending her brood. Is it not her nature to strike at invaders?

152.speaker: Kagha
152.text: Don't we? I've studied drow culture. You have a talent for self-preservation.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: I have no love for the Queen of Spiders.

27.speaker: Kagha
27.text: Indeed? But you do exhibit a talent for self-preservation.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: I worship Eilistraee - not the Queen of Spiders.

30.speaker: Kagha
30.text: Indeed? Then above all, you must have a talent for self-preservation.

31.speaker: Kagha
31.text: Away. I have no more need of you.
31.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

53.speaker: Kagha
53.text: Indeed? Then when the lightning comes, it has one fewer to strike.

202.speaker: Kagha
202.text: I do hope you didn't come expecting my thanks. That would be most perplexing.

63.speaker: Kagha
63.text: Why are you here? I sent you to Zevlor.
63.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

65.speaker: Kagha
65.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

70.speaker: Kagha
70.text: Go on. Say it. You think I'm a monster.
70.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Monster? Too kind. A demon, more like.
115.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

161.speaker: Wyll
161.text: Monster? Too kind. A demon, more like.
161.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Do you expect pity? You killed a child in cold blood.
48.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

44.speaker: Player
44.text: Do you expect pity? You killed a child in cold blood.
44.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

78.speaker: Kagha
78.text: You've the skin of a beast. If only your heart was so bold.

116.speaker: Kagha
116.text: I know your kind. You see only victims and villains.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Only a monster would threaten a child.
29.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

72.speaker: Kagha
72.text: I know your kind from other circles. You see only villains and victims.

25.speaker: Kagha
25.text: A viper bares her fangs defending her brood. I call her mother. You call her monster.

105.speaker: Kagha
105.text: Yes - you would say so. I know your kind. You see only villains and victims.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: You're protecting your own - sometimes cruelty is required.
165.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

106.speaker: Kagha
106.text: First you urge grace. Then you speak truth. To think a devil could surprise me twice over.

71.speaker: Kagha
71.text: First you urge grace. Then you speak truth. You've surprised me twice over.

32.speaker: Kagha
32.text: A shame the grace period ends. The viper's fangs have been bared. She must guard her brood.

164.speaker: Kagha
164.text: First, you stay silent. Then, you speak truth. To think an outsider could surprise me twice over.

191.speaker: Player
191.text: Honestly, I just wanted to see what would happen.
191.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

66.speaker: Kagha
66.text: Ah - you don't see a monster. You just look at me through one's eyes.
66.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

104.speaker: Kagha
104.text: You are like all the rest. Where devils tread, chaos follows.
104.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

5.speaker: Kagha
5.text: You are like the devils. Where they tread, chaos follows.
5.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

201.speaker: Kagha
201.text: No matter. I took back the Idol of Silvanus and the rite has resumed. We will seal the grove. Free from harm. Free of intruders.
201.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: I know the truth. You mean to take the grove for the Shadow Druids.
19.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

64.speaker: Kagha
64.context: CinematicNodeContext: The rats transform into Druids. This leads to the Denouncing scene.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: This rite must be born of powerful magic.
37.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

98.speaker: Kagha
98.text: The Rite of Thorns. It is the Treefather's gift, that none come to harm. When we speak the final prayer, the Great Vine will sprout forth.
98.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

187.speaker: Kagha
187.text: The grove will be cloaked in bramble and thorn. No one enters, no one leaves. Sanctuary.
187.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

148.speaker: Narrator
148.text: *Past teachings come into focus. The Rite of Thorns is a rare practice, outlawed in most circles for causing more harm than it eases.*
148.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

111.speaker: Kagha
111.text: None of this can happen while outlanders infect us. Silvanus demands that we choke them out.
111.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: You'd leave them to die on the road.
20.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

95.speaker: Kagha
95.text: I am First Druid now. I protect the circle, whatever the cost.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: I came on Zevlor's behalf. His people could perish if you force them out.
82.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

177.speaker: Kagha
177.text: And mine perish if he stays.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: What does forcing them out achieve? They've done nothing.
0.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: You must let them stay. They've done nothing to harm you.
109.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: You cast out the guiltless. You shame your order.
138.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: Turning your back on the needy - is this truly the way of Silvanus?
26.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

10.speaker: Kagha
10.text: 'A disease of the flower must not reach the root. Pluck the petals. Sever the branch if you must. But cut out the rot before it infects the whole of the wood.'

56.speaker: Kagha
56.text: Teachings of Silvanus, you must agree.

23.speaker: Kagha
23.text: Teachings of the Treefather. Do you agree?

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I know the Treefather's teachings as well as you.

131.speaker: Kagha
131.text: Then you know I heed his wisdom. I protect the circle, whatever the cost.

194.speaker: Kagha
194.text: You showed great mettle at the gate - the mettle of a skilled sword for hire.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: I hardly know every line of doctrine.

203.speaker: Kagha
203.text: Then why do you doubt my acts and intent?

58.speaker: Kagha
58.text: You showed great mettle at the gate - the mettle of a skilled sword for hire.

172.speaker: Kagha
172.text: They're to be gone before final prayer. If they are not...

86.speaker: Player
86.text: The viper can stand down. Zevlor is already dead.

157.speaker: Kagha
157.text: Indeed? Then removing his people should provide you little challenge.

14.speaker: Player
14.text: I'll see what can be done about them.

92.speaker: Kagha
92.text: This tale ends but one way: with the outlander rot cleansed and the grove forever shrouded.

167.speaker: Player
167.text: I've done enough. They're your problem, not mine.

128.speaker: Kagha
128.text: Then they soon know the sting of my venom.

188.speaker: Kagha
188.text: Get out. We have no more business.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Then it seems I'd best speak to Zevlor.

88.speaker: Kagha
88.text: You will do more than speak.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: Prattle all you want. The refugees aren't my concern.

38.speaker: Kagha
38.text: I want you to provide your services to the tiefling leader - Zevlor, he's called. Offer to guide the outlanders out of the grove. I'm sure they'll reward you well.

162.speaker: Kagha
162.text: I want you to provide your services to Zevlor. Offer to guide the outlanders out of the grove. I'm sure they'll reward you well.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: Words you have twisted to justify your cruelty.

175.speaker: Kagha
175.text: Words I heed to the letter to keep my brood safe.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: Turning your back on the needy - is this truly the way of Silvanus?
85.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: Do what you want. It's none of my concern.
87.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

76.speaker: Kagha
76.text: So you say. Yet you share their infernal blood.

102.speaker: Kagha
102.text: Ah yes. You like to meddle. See what happens. So let me tell you what happens next.

123.speaker: Kagha
123.text: You will offer your services to the tieflings' leader - Zevlor, he's called. And you will guide the outlanders out of the grove.

184.speaker: Kagha
184.text: You will offer your services to Zevlor, guide the outlanders out of the grove.

16.speaker: Kagha
16.text: Then I was wise to grant you entry. And you'd be wise to heed my words.

144.speaker: Kagha
144.text: So you say. Yet you share their infernal blood. And the child walks free.

21.speaker: Kagha
21.text: So you say. Yet the child walks free.

94.speaker: Player
94.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

197.speaker: Kagha
197.text: Stay your hand. This is neither the time nor the place.
197.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

6.speaker: Lae'zel
6.text: Stay your hand. This is neither the time nor the place.
6.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

150.speaker: Kagha
150.text: Have you finished your chatter? Then you will give me your ear.

196.speaker: Shadowheart
196.text: Keep talking. Nothing to be gained in picking a fight with a fanatic.
196.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

34.speaker: Karlach
34.text: Hang on. If we play this right, we might be able to stop this before it starts.
34.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

174.speaker: Astarion
174.context: NodeContext: You've been bored, now you're ready to rip someone's throat out.

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: Think it through. Anger Kagha, and the whole grove could suffer.

170.speaker: Gale
170.text: Hold. Give diplomacy a chance to do its job.

108.speaker: Kagha
108.text: The outlander serves Zevlor! Circle - to arms. Let no parasite live!

96.speaker: Kagha
96.text: The outlander serves Zevlor! Circle - to arms. Let no parasite live!

135.speaker: Player
135.text: Zevlor sent me. His people won't survive out there.

178.speaker: Kagha
178.text: They may die on the road.

193.speaker: Kagha
193.text: They will die if they stay.

57.speaker: Kagha
57.text: A clear choice, I would say.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: Zevlor believes his people will perish on the road.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: You can't just force these people out.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: What does forcing them out achieve? They've done nothing.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: Free from the threat of little children?

55.speaker: Kagha
55.text: She stole the Idol of Silvanus during prayer, and interrupted the rite.

101.speaker: Kagha
101.text: Why, I don't know or care.

163.speaker: Player
163.text: Not at all. That was quite a show.

59.speaker: Kagha
59.text: Monsters both, then. Viper to viper. Beast to beast.

51.speaker: Kagha
51.text: Monsters both, then. Viper to viper.

180.speaker: Player
180.text: That depends. It was an accident - wasn't it?

117.speaker: Kagha
117.text: Accidents do not exist. There is only choice and consequence.

99.speaker: Kagha
99.text: The devilspawn imperilled my brood. I bared my fangs to defend it. Choice. Consequence.

97.speaker: Kagha
97.text: Now the Idol of Silvanus is returned and the rite has resumed. We will seal the grove. Free from harm. Free of intruders.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Your iron will is impressive - if a touch inflexible.

139.speaker: Kagha
139.text: You speak in paradox. I care not for steel, but I know if it bends - it breaks. I will not allow this grove to be broken.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: The Rite of Thorns is risky magic. Is it not banned in your circle?

160.speaker: Kagha
160.text: And if it is? Strangers are the scourge; the rite is the remedy. No laws can change that.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: This rite must be born of powerful magic.

199.speaker: Player
199.text: I'm told there is a healer here. Where is she?

190.speaker: Kagha
190.text: Nettie, yes. She's bumbling about somewhere.

24.speaker: Kagha
24.text: But if your treatment is meant to outlast the rite, you'll be removed with the rest.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: Zevlor's people need refuge. You can't deny them that.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: That child - what was her crime?

42.speaker: Player
42.text: Zevlor wants you removed. I'm here to see it done.

89.speaker: Kagha
89.text: A grey dwarf - in our grove, on this day. A sign. Or rather, a gift.

52.speaker: Kagha
52.text: Who better to understand a watchful broodmother than one who hails from... below?
